When a second mock is created for the same class, dispose of the dynamically created subclass for the first mock.

Previously that first dynamically created subclass was kept around forever,
and if accessed somehow (for example by enumerating objc_getClassList) would
always raise NSInternalInconsistencyException.

Merge pull request #345 from sdefresne/target

Fix for #338.
Added preliminary workaround for #339.

Allow compilation with old deployment targets.

The function object_isClass is only available starting from macOS
10.10 and iOS 8.0 SDKs. To allow targeting older systems (i.e. if
the deployment target is older), add an alternate implementation.

The implementation is based on the one used by the Swift runtime:
https://github.com/apple/swift/pull/11467/commits/0475307c08

Fixes issue #344.

Fix comparison of struct type representation.

When building with iOS 11 SDK and running on iOS 10 device, the type
representation, some of structure type are incompatible and are not
considered equal even though they are.

This fixes the comparison by:

1.  properly parsing nested subtypes like {Foo={Bar={B}}}
2.  considering that a struct without a name {} is equal to any struct
3.  not use NSGetSizeAndAlignment to parse subtype like {__rep}

Fixes issue #342.

Merge branch 'iangithubusername-Issue171'

Removed code that tried to make setup/verify thread-safe.

The goal is to make use of the mock objects thread safe. Setup and verify should still happen for the main thread. Hence there's no reason to complicate the code trying to make the setup/verify (partially) thread-safe.
Small stylistic changes.
Removing need for Objective-C++ in HamcrestTests.
Allow mocking managed objects.

OCMockObject is not thread safe

Make OCMockObject thread safe.

Synchronize on the four mutable array instance variables during access to ensure their consistency.
Retain everything retrieved from the arrays if the retrieved objects ever get used outside of the synchronized chunks.

Retain captured invocation arguments since the arguments could otherwise be deallocated at any time. The invocation can't outright retain its arguments since that would cause a retain cycle, so use a customized method to retain arguments that filters out self.
Add all the reference counting methods (-retainCount, -retain, -release, -autorelease) to OCPartialMockObject's selector black list. They're a recipe for stack overflow since partial mocks set up a forwarder for -retain. The forwarder would capture the call to -retain as an NSInvocation, OCMockObject now retains the invocation arguments, which calls -retain on the original object again, which hits the forwarder method again, and so on and so forth.

Make OCMMacroState thread safe as well.

Having a global macro state doesn't work. With locking it doesn't crash, but if two threads are recording at the same time then one of the macro states gets stepped on. Change the global state to be a per-thread state.
Avoid a use-after-dealloc race by not trying to clear the global state in -dealloc and making the macros exception safe such that the +endXXXMacro calls always happen even if the captured invocation throws an exception.

Make OCObserverMockObject thread safe.

Synchronize on the two mutable array instance variables during access to ensure their consistency.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:erikdoe/ocmock
Fixed copyright notice.
Workaround for failing test.
Initial import of iOS9 example project.
(#207) Hotfix - removed reference to dead test file 'OCMBlockArgCallerTests.m'.

(#207) Expressly set default values.

- Defaults for objective-c objects, pointers and numeric values are now
  manually constructed (nil, NULL and 0 respectively).
- Where constructing a default is impractical, the constraint throws an
  NSInvalidArgumentException, prompting the user to define their own
  default. For example, for a struct argument.
- New tests - all passing.
(#207) Fixed integration issues with new changes to OCMFunctionsPrivate header.

(#207) Adhered to OCMock coding style.

- No space between if, for, while, etc and proceeding brace.
- Curley braces are on their own line.
- Ivars names are not prefixed with an underscore.
- Removed redundant _inv ivar whilst - buildInvocationFromBlock now
  returns an NSInvocation directly.

(#207) Assertions for non-object types.

- Added assertion for parameters that should be boxed (e.g. of type
  NSValue)
- Tested.

(#207) Less strict constraints on passing numerical arguments.

- Moved OCMNumberTypeForObjCType from NSValue+OCMAdditions to
  OCMFunctions.
- Used OCMNumberTypeForObjCType to determine whether we can bypass
  the type assertion in OCMBlockArgCaller.

(#207) Refined how OCMBlockArgCaller deals with certain pointer types.

- Don't necessarily allow void * for any pointer arg type.
- Started implementing a test for more complex block params.
- Allowed any ptr to be passed as ^v.

(#207) Further refined how [OCMArg invokeBlockWithArgs:...] deals with its argument list.

- Added NS_REQUIRES_NIL_TERMINATION.
- Made notes on why we don't pass the va_list to OCMBlockArgCaller and extract
  them at call-time.
- Added tests for default args.
- Removed some unnecessary macros.
(#207) Memory management - passing static analyzer.

(#207) First implementation of [OCMArg invokeBlock].

- Untested impl.
- Updated inline comments.

(#207) Refined how non-objects are handled.

- NSMethodSignature now dictates how to extract the arguments and assert
  that they are of the correct type.
- NSNull parameters are ignored (default).
- Removed redundant OCMArgsEnd

(#207) Passing tests for OCMBlockArgCaller.

- Tests pass with both NSString and *BOOL block arguments.
- Started documenting some potential limitations in inline comments

(#207) First implementation of [OCMArg invokeBlockWithArgs:..].

- [OCMArg invokeBlockWithArgs:..] takes a va_list of boxed block parameters,
  constructs an NSArray from them and passes it to the OCMBlockArgCaller.
- OCMBlockArgCaller extracts and unboxes the params as dictated by the block's
  NSMethodSignature, before using them to configure an NSInvocation.
- The NSInvocation is invoked with the block as its target.
Fix for #247.

Merge pull request #249 from carllindberg/FixClassIsKindOfClass

Fix isKindOfClass on class objects

Calling -isKindOfClass: on class objects is weird -- it only returns YES if NSObject is the argument.  This is because it is the NSObject instance method version which is being inherited by the class (class objects are essentially instances of NSObject).  For checking inheritance with classes, the +isSubclassOfClass: method is provided.

Removed direct usages of isa pointer.  That is a bad idea these days because of tagged pointers -- the raw pointer values may not be valid Class objects.  They were only used to manipulate meta classes though and those may have been OK.  However, object_getClass and object_setClass works just fine for them.

Fix linking in Objective–C++ tests.

This commit solves that problem by conditionally declaring `OCMMakeLocation` as `extern C` in when included in a C++ compilation unit.

Implement support for converting between NSNumber/NSValue types, but raise if the conversion is not lossless.  Solves a number of problems with different BOOL types ('c' vs 'B') and method signature vs NSValue types which can differ a little in different architectures.
Also add support for comparing opaque pointer types versus the same pointer which knows the contents of the structure.

Silence warnings when passing invocations

When passing invocations that return values, you can end up with
compiler warnings that you're not using the result (for example, when
verifying that an `init` method is called). This isn't ideal, and leads
to having to add ugly `#pragma clang` definitions in your test file.
Instead, we can use the C99 `_Pragma()` function to disable these
warnings inside the macros themselves.

Fix exception when an object has a nil description

An exception is thrown when an object parameter of an invocation has a nil description as the result of [object description] is directly passed to appendString: in the invocationDescription method.  This pull request fixes the issue by returning an empty string instead of nil.

Support rare cases where the @encoding of a typedefed-type appends multiple „@„ within the encoding

changed isNS*__ method handling

partial mock would go into infinite loop when checking `isSubclass` instead of `kindOfClass`

removed partial mocking of mock in description test

OCMock doesn't seem to handle mocking of proxy objects well.  I think this can fairly be considered a rare (and dubiously useful) case.  As such, I'm content with the test passing without verification that the __isNS* methods are being called.

Revert "added OCMAdditions category to NSProxy"

This reverts commit 1bb77abe5f1da82d40a88ca5a111b86888ea5f27.

added tests for description handling stubs

apparently this is only a problem on iOS 6, so UIDevice is used to only expect the methods when the sim is running in iOS 6.

added OCMAdditions category to NSProxy

this allows for partial mocking of mocks (for internal testing)

added built-in class mock tolerance for handling description implementation for NS* container classes

For example, if an OCClassMockObject is inside an NSDictionary and some part of the test code calls -[NSDictionary description] (for example, when logging the contents of the dictionary to the console), then these isNS*__ methods are called on its contents.

It's reasonable to expect this to be tolerated since it shouldn't have any effect on test results, and is simply an annoyance to the tester to write extra for stubs for things that aren't relevant to the test.

Add OCMockLibTests target for running unit tests on an iOS device or simulator.

Updates when using Xcode 5.0.1 on MacOS X 10.9, and also for arm64 iOS targets.
It looks like all the *_stret functions do not exist in the arm64 runtime, so we can't even reference them in code and must #ifdef them out.
Also on arm64, BOOL seems to be encoded as "bool" (the 'B' objcType, or _C_BOOL) rather than the historical 'c', but NSValue can still use 'c', so we need to have those compare as equal.
There are warnings now when undeclared methods are used in @selector statements, so add some @interface sections to quiet the warnings.
In one place, a method lookup wasn't working (@dynamic property) but we still got a method signature, so changed to use the passed-in SEL.
fixed undeclared selector warnings

Merge pull request #7 from KushalP/master

Fix warnings appearing in clang version 3.1 (trunk 148911)

Use protocol_getName() over -name

Import <objc/Protocol.h> to make it clear to the compiler the [Protocol
-name] was made unavailable in the 10.6+ SDK.

Instead, grab the protocol name using protocol_getName() which is found
within <objc/runtime.h> and is available on 10.7 and (at least) iOS 4.3.
Clarified readme.
Remove the use of UTF8String; stick to using just name
wrap the return to make sure that it's a string

Use object_getClass instead of isa

It's not possible to replace isa usage with isKindOfClass: for pointers
that aren't objects. This fixes that.
Added a test to explore the last warning in this Chromium bug: http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=113894

Fix warnings appearing in clang version 3.1 (trunk 148911)
